message_1: Consider the unit square in the plane, i.e., the set $S=[0,1]\times [0,1]$ with the usual metric. Show that there exists a triangulation of $S$ with at most $10$ triangles.
message_2:
To show that there exists a triangulation of the unit square $S$ with at most $10$ triangles, we will provide an explicit construction of such a triangulation.

Divide the unit square into four smaller squares of side length $1/2$. Now, divide each of these smaller squares into two right triangles by drawing a diagonal. This gives us a total of $4 \times 2 = 8$ triangles.

However, we can further improve this triangulation. Consider the central square formed by the intersection of the diagonals of the four smaller squares. This central square has side length $1/2$. Divide this central square into two right triangles by drawing a diagonal. Now, we have a total of $8 - 4 + 2 = 6$ triangles.

Finally, consider the four corner triangles of the unit square. Divide each of these corner triangles into two smaller triangles by drawing a diagonal from the right angle vertex to the midpoint of the hypotenuse. This adds $4 \times 1 = 4$ triangles to our triangulation.

Thus, we have a triangulation of the unit square $S$ with a total of $6 + 4 = 10$ triangles.
